name: f19m2
probTex: Show that $f(z)=|z|^2$ has a derivative only at the origin.
solnTex:
First we rewrite $f$ as $f(z)=z\overline z$. The difference quotient is
\[\lim_{h\to0}\frac{(z+h)\overline{(z+h)}-z\overline z}{h}=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{z\overline h+h\overline z+h\overline h}{h}.\]
The $h$ cancels on the last two terms, giving
\[=z\left(\lim_{h\to0}\frac{\overline h}{h}\right)+\overline z+\lim_{h\to0}\overline h=z\left(\lim_{h\to0}\frac{(\overline h)}{h}\right)+\overline z.\]
As we all know, $\lim_{h\to0}\frac{(\overline h)}{h}$ is ill-defined, we can see this by taking $h=\alpha t$ for $\alpha=1,i$ and taking $t\to 0$. The ill-definedness persists precisely when $z\neq0$; if $z=0$ the problem doesn't matter because the 0 annihilates the numerator. Thus $f$ has a derivative only at $z=0$.
